title: ISic001763. I.Sicily inscription 001763
body:
Facsimile Images

[Δι]ονυσία κ(αὶ) ((ivy-leaf))
[Πο]μ̣πη((·))ί((·))α ἡ ταύ-
της θυγάτη͡ρ ἐνθάδ͡ε
(scil. κῖντε) [προ]χ̣ωρήσασε (scil. ἐν) θ(ε)ῷ
5[ἡ] μ̣ήτηρ π͡ρ͡ὸ ιη´ κ(αλανδῶν) ὀκτ(οβρίων)
[ὑ]π(ατείᾳ) Μ͡αλλίῳ Θεοδώρ(ῳ)
ἡ θυγάτη͡ρ πρ(ὸ) ((·)) θ´ ((·)) κ(αλανδῶν) ((·))
φεβρ(ουαρίων) ((·)) μ͡ε͡τ(ὰ) τὴ͡ν ὑπ(α)τία(ν)
Ἀρκαδίου ((·)) κ(αὶ) ((·)) Ὁνω
10ρίου σ(εβαστῶν) ((·)) τὸ ((·)) ε´ ((·))

Apparatus criticus

Text of Wessel, supplemented by transcription of Orsi

English translation

Dionysia and Pompeia(?), her daughter, (lie) here, departed in god, the mother 18 days before the kalends of October [14 September] in the consulship of Mallios Theodoros [399 CE], the daughter 9 days before the kalends of February [24 January] following the fifth consulship of Arkadios and Honorios, the Augusti [402 CE]

commentary

As Ferrua observes, the unusual form of the consular dating for the daughter's death suggests that the notice of the new consuls for 403 CE had not yet reached Syracusae when the epitaph was engraved.

bibliography

  • Orsi 1893 284 no.22 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001715
  • Strazzulla 1897 138 no. 166 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001390
  • Ferrua 1982-1983 9 no. 21, 11 no. 29 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10001996
  • Wessel 1989 183 no. 778 https://biblio.inscriptiones.org/epig10000394
Licensed under a Creative Commons-Attribution 4.0 licence.
